lmports of textiles and clothing were included in consumer goods until.l 984. Since 1985, textiles imported as raw material for garment exportswere classif ied under intermediate goods.

(a) Net Domestic Assets (NDA) is equal to Net Credit to Government(NCG) plus claims on public corporations plus claims on privatesector plus other items (net).(b) The amount of currency, including subsidiary notes and coins heldby the public(c) Demand deposits held by the public.(d) Time and savings deposits held by the public(e) Includes outward bills(l) The CBSL adopted International Accounting Standards in preparingthe CBSL balance sheet since January 2002, Accordingly, foreignassets have been recorded at market values, which reflects its

Source; Central Bank of Sri Lankaimpact in NFA and a NDA in Monetary Authorities in the table. Therefore, these items are norcomparable with those prior to Dec, 2002,credit extended to the government by the banking system, net ol government deposits withbanks and government cash balances

Monetary data from 1990 have been reclassified as follows, to be consistent with standardinternational oractice

Demand deposits held by the public:-Exclude the value ol rupee demand deposits held by customers resident oulside Sri Lanka,These deposits are now lreated as foreign liabilities,

Time and savings deposils held by the public:-Exclude the value of rupee time and savings deposits held by customers resident outsideSri Lanka, These deposits are now treated as f oreign liabilities.

Borrowings inexcess of this quota were sublected to a penal interest rate of 15 per cent per annum, In Seplember 1979, a graduated scale ol penal rates rangingfrom.l 500percentto25.0Opercentwasintroduced ltwasfurtherrevisedupwardtoarangeol 20percentto30percent,witheffectfromApril 1980,With effect from August 1980, the Bank Rate was raised to 14 per cent, while lhe penal rales were raised to a range ol 21 per cent to 30 per cent.ln March 1983, the Bank Rate was broughl down to 13 per cent and the penal rate was fixed al2O per cent. With etfect from 23 November 1983, thepraclice of granting advances to commercial banks under the penal rate was discontinued With effect from 30 December 1985, the Central Bankreduced the lending rates on its advances to 1 1 per cent.
